headline.print_headline: As New Lawyer, Senator Defended Big Tobacco
headline.seo: As a Young Lawyer, Gillibrand Defended Big Tobacco
headline.main: As New Lawyer, Senator Was Active in Tobacco’s Defense

byline.original: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ and DAVID KOCIENIEWSKI

docs.lead_paragraph: In the 1990s, Kirsten Gillibrand played a significant role in fighting government attempts to prove wrongdoing by cigarette makers.
docs.snippet: In the 1990s, Kirsten Gillibrand played a significant role in fighting government attempts to prove wrongdoing by cigarette makers.

headline.main: As New Lawyer, Senator Defended Big Tobacco

docs.abstract: Kirsten Gillibrand, who was appointed to US Senate from New York in January, worked on behalf of Phillip Morris Co as young lawyer in 1990s, defending company against perjury investigation brought by Justice Dept and helping to keep from public view research it had conducted in Germany that showed connection between smoking and cancer; contends she was only junior associate with little control over cases she handled and limited involvement in defending tobacco maker, but she was in fact involved in most sensitive matters related to defense of tobacco giant as it confronted pivotal legal battles; overview of her work on behalf of tobacco company given; photos (L)
docs.section_name: Front Page; New York and Region

byline.original: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ and DAVID KOCIENIEWSKI

docs.lead_paragraph: The Philip Morris Company did not like to talk about what went on inside its lab in Cologne, Germany, where researchers secretly conducted experiments exploring the effects of cigarette smoking. So when the Justice Department tried to get its hands on that research in 1996 to prove that tobacco industry executives had lied about the dangers of smoking, the company moved to fend off the effort with the help of a highly regarded young lawyer named Kirsten Rutnik.

headline.print_headline: Extra Vitamin E: No Benefit, Maybe Harm
headline.main: Extra Vitamin E: No Benefit, Maybe Harm

docs.lead_paragraph: Does vitamin E do anything to help prevent cancer, Alzheimer’s disease or heart disease?
docs.snippet: Does vitamin E do anything to help prevent cancer, Alzheimer’s disease or heart disease?

headline.main: Extra Vitamin E: No Benefit, Maybe Harm

docs.lead_paragraph: About three decades ago at a scientific conference on aging, just about every presenter was taking vitamin E, a nutrient with antioxidant properties that, it was thought, would slow the cellular ravages of age. In subsequent years, many reports from observational and case studies suggested that vitamin E in daily doses far greater than recommended could help to stave off heart disease and stroke, various common cancers, dementia and Alzheimer's disease, cataracts and macular degeneration, respiratory tract infections and a host of other serious and sometimes fatal health problems.
